description: This is best chinese food restaurant in San Francisco. We've dined at this restaurant many times. The restaurant is very clean and well decorated. The staff is professional and nice. We also order from this restaurant weekly. We love the food and enjoy a wide range id dishes. If you want high quality chinese food and a good eating experience order from Xiao Long Restaurant. We love the dried fried string beans, chicken and calamari. There are also great vegetarian options.
author: X X.

description:
i'm torn between 2 1/2 and 3.

had the sizzling rice soup, xiao loong beef and dry fried calamari.

sizzling soup - ehhh and it didn't sizzle all too much? I dont know. whatever.
xiao loong beef - extremely smoky tasting, which i didn't enjoy but the beef was tender and cooked perfectly. the seasoning just wasn't my cup of tea.
dry fried calamari - good and i actually enjoyed this. however, it was a tad on the SALTY side. 

i'm really thirsty now. =(
author: Susy C.

description:
I walked in this place expecting an American Chinese restuarant and I wasn't off the mark.  But maybe my expectation for something decent was asking for too much.  All the dishes we order came with a gloopy sauce that was all sweet, sour, salty, and spicy that was not appealing.

The wait staff kind of hung around and pretty much ignored us most of the time.  And who the heck charges for rice when you order main dishes, that should just come with the food.  

This is not chinese food and I know I won't ever go back.
author: Twist' D.

description:
We shared the Xiao Loong Bow appetizer and the Kung Pao Chicken with a round of Tsingtao .... we were both starving upon entry and satisfying stuffed upon exit.  

very good!
author: Sarah K.

description:
Of course it's Americanized Chinese food, just look at the place, but that doesn't make it negative at all.  I mean, consider the demographics of the neighborhood.

Anyway, the xiao loong bow here are good.  So is the lamb mushu.  Just make sure you don't order the xiao loong bow to go, unless you want your car and house to stink like feet.  I do mind the smell, but it's just too good to pass up when I have that specific craving.

And I think the service is pretty good.  One time I called ahead for pick up and they were about to close.  They offered to stay open until I could make it there.  Nice.
author: spiff e.

description:
Best Chinese food ever. 
Take out is awesome, eating in is even better.
My personal favorites: 
braised fish, house chicken, dry fried calamari and Xiao Loong beef.

My only regret is that since I moved from the Sunset to Pot Hill I don't get to eat here all that often.

Oh and the owner, Jeff, is a great guy.
author: Mark S.

description: The food here is super consistent and always really good. True gourmet Chinese.  Also very nice friendly service.  Their take out is also fast and delicious. LOVE the Xiao Loong Chicken.
author: Bryon W.

description: I've been going to this restaurant for probably 7 years now.  The items I love (pot stickers, combo rice, chicken salad, house chicken, dry fried calamari, dry fried shrimp, dry fried green beans, lemon chicken, and OMG, their steamed fish is great!) are consistently wonderful.  The wait staff is friendly and attentive, and the owner is frequently pitching in with the staff.  The place is clean and I just love eating here!
author: Jill T.

description:
I tried Xiao Loong several times hoping, just HOPING, that I would have a nice lunch. My hopes never turned into reality. 

The food is bland and oversauced (a bland sauce at that). I had an HK style noodle once, a spicy tofu dish over rice, and another dish that I can't even remember. I gave it several tries out of desperation and was disappointed every time. 

The two stars is for the very nice and helpful staff.
author: Christine C.

description:
I've been to this place about 5 times.  We've had take out, we've been there with our friends with small kids.  We've been there during busy hours and we've been there during less busy hours.  
Xiao Loong is consistantly good.  They take care of their customers, and they have good food.  
Is this authentic?  I don't know and I don't really care.  The food is good, the service is good, and the place is right.
author: Nelson W.

description:
I've been to this establishment twice and have been quite impressed both times.  I am welcomed right away and am escorted to my table.  Drinks are served almost immediately soon after.  I've had the pleasure of trying their chicken & shitake mushroom soup, shrimp dumplings, garlic eggplant, shitake mushroom and bok choy, sweet and sour pork and spicy dry fried chicken (not all on one visit, of course!).  

The decor is very modern, the staff very inviting. Their prices are very affordable, especially for lunch.  For less than $10, you'll be able to get an appetizer, soup, rice and sizable entree!

Since moving to the Bay Area, I have never come close to finding chinese food as good as on the East coast.  It's just my luck that, three months before I move back, I finally find one.
author: PauLine R.

description:
If you like San Tung on Irving and/or Panda Express served up more fancy, you will like this place!

Ok, that sounds reaaaally weird but 1) they have dry fried chicken & green beans just like San Tung (which we got and it was good) and 2) the food here is on the Americanized like Panda but it's more Chinese... and definitely not fast food... ok that was a bad comparison but you know what I mean!

Small, cute, cozy restaurant -- just like everything else along West Portal, and definitely not your typical greasy-feeling/smelling Chinese joint. Excellent service (thanks Rich!) and food comes out quickly. Also great selection of teas -- we had the chrysanthemum. Only downside is that there is no waiting area so you usually wait outside but they do give you a call when a table is ready.
author: Miss H.

description:
This is what Chinese food should taste like.  Jeff knew what he was doing when he opened up this place.  The ambiance is classy and the service is phenomenal.  They have a great selection of dumplings, though personally I like the pot stickers.  They're huge and a little oily (but what do you expect?), but they are REALLY tasty.

They have a Mongolian Lamb to die for, with angry red chilies staring you down as you scoop up the delicious goodness onto your plate.    It is very easy to order too much food here because it all looks so darn good.  On the other hand, you get a tasty lunch (or breakfast) the next day so it's totally worth it.

The steamed fish seems to be a popular dish, but it is a big portion and usually it is too much for two people.  Good for family style though.  The spicy tofu and string beans are great as are ALL of their clay pot dishes.

You do have to pay for tea, which kind of bucks the trend of other Chinese restaurants, however the selection of tea is much better than what you'll find on Irving Street or Clement Street.  Incidentally, their tea selection is only to be outdone by their wine selection.  Jeff knows quite a bit about wine, and if you're a wine snob, you can definitely trust his selection.  

All in all, this is a great place to take a date, or go with your family (both of which I've done.)  I do wish they delivered, but c'est la vie.  I highly recommend this place.
author: Adam E.

description:
Good food and ambience...

I was amazed at how fast the food came out...

The waitress/hostess is pretty damned hot...
author: Nathan W.

description: We just happened upon this great little place while walking in West Portal one afternoon, and have fallen in love with the place.   The waitstaff is so attentive and very pleasant, and the food is very, very good.   I highly recommend their Mu Shu Pork and their Crab Dumplings, but everything has been consistently good when we've dined there.  And we ALWAYS have food left over for the next day or so.
author: Michael S.

description: They were okay. Nothing spectacular. I would come here again. But am I beating their door down? Nah but they service was excellent!
author: Sophie P.

description: My husband and I eat here often.  He likes Chinese food more than I but I really enjoy this restaurant.  The service is quick and very friendly and the staff remembers our favorite dishes.  I particularly like the sizzling rice soup.  Last night I had the lemon chicken that I enjoy but is a bit sweet for my husband's taste.  The decor is very clean and sleek.  Nice to have such a lovely restaurant nearby.
author: Vicki B.

description:
Xiao Lung Bao Rating: 1 star

I can't believe nobody mentioned that the Xiao Loong Bao served at "XIAO LOONG" restaurant cannot be classified as Xiao Loong Bao at all. Even 7X7 magazine did not catch that. We even asked for the dark Chinese Chinkiang vinegar with shredded ginger, (CATCH THIS) they do not have it. 

However, food was generally quite good. I thought the prawn and chives steamed dumplings were approaching San Tung's. Dumpling skin did not taste hand-made. Service was excellent. Friends were saying this is a notch up from PF Chang and I thought that was a bit harsh.
author: DANIEL T.

description: The food here rocks! Hot braised fish (fried and garlicky goodness) and pan pacific wontons (the flakiest pastry stuffed with cream cheese and crab) are the best in town by far!
author: Daniel K.

description:
Went here last night, had 
 - potstickers - i don;t think you can ruin these
 - eggplant - tasty, the best dish
 - green beans - tasty but needs more chilli
 - beef Xiao Loong - kinda boring, but pretty good

The restaurant looks good, and we had good service.

The west portal location is too convenient, because its only 3 stops for us on the Muni tram, and it's serviced by 3 lines, so we can get there quickly, and back on the same ticket.
author: Ed R.

description:
Been twice for dinner now, had good food and good service.  One dish was a bit too sweet, but everything else has been very tasty.  An interesting touch is the hot and sour soup has shrimp in it.  Highly recommend the lemon pepper prawns.

Most recent experience - really different and I have to move the rating down.  Greasy, lacking in flavor, really odd soup broth (potentially burned.)  Oh well...
author: Spike S.

description: Decent Chinese food--nothing spectacular, but nothing horrible either. The spicy dishes werent that spicy at all, but they give you hot sauce on the table to make your own heat. The tables are packed tightly together and I think we might have horrified the couple next to us with our conversation about this woman who claimed to have pus-filled diarrhea.  Yes, we should have shut-up.
author: brewgirl b.

description:
We've been going here since it opened (and believe me, it's a vast improvement over the previous Chinese restaurant), and we usually go with 3 generations...my grandmother, my folks and me. It pleases all. And yes, we often are the only Chinese faces there.

Things we always order: the xiao loong bow, the hot and sour soup (++), and the Hong Kong-style chow mein with chicken/mushrooms. You can't go wrong with these.
author: Leah B.

description:
The service is very attentive. The owner Jeff is always around to make sure everything is just as you had ordered. And if you do not know what to get, there are always the staff recommendations, which we have found to be very tasty.

My kids actually eat from this restaurant, so in our book, makes this place a utopic haven for culinary bliss in a manageable environment.

The favorites are the chicken salad, Xioa Loong bows,(excellent) and mushu prawns with the five extra pancakes. This is a great neighborhhod joint. Locals share info on everything from politics to whats hot and going on in the neighborhood.

A very family friendly environment and though the restaurant can get crowded, it's never too crowded for the kids.

A great option to the other chinese restaurants around town, parking is quite abundant in the neighborhood and we ofter find parking right in front... BONUS!!! Especially with two kids.

Kudos to the Xiao Loong team!!!
author: robert C.

description: I've eaten there many times, love the original recipes and how they cook food very hot and fast. Love the strong, flavorful sauces. This is not the same experience as most other Chinese restaurants in the city, a couple of notches up, marginally more expensive but worth it.
author: Jairo W.

description:
I can't even say how appalled I am with the food I had at this place. This restaurant is so far removed from Chinese food that I'm embarrassed for the owners. I am Chinese, and having just gotten back from a trip to China last week, eating at this place was excruciating. 

We had the Spicy Chili Prawns, and it was basically a plate of de-shelled shrimps swimming in ketchup. I wish I were exaggerating, but I'm not. The other dish we had was Family Style Chili Pepper Tofu.  It was so overwhelmingly bland and watery from the sprouts, and the vegetables didn't taste like anything!!!! And I always hate Chinese restaurants that charge for rice. 

This place sucks. Don't eat here. Trust me.
author: Linda Q.

description:
Well, first you might wanna know how to pronounce the name; it's "shao lon."

I don't even know how many times I've been there. One of my favorite restaurants in the city! The food is delicious, the atmosphere is nice, and the price is decent with a big portion. If you expect Chinese food, go elsewhere, because this is a Hong Kong style restaurant.

If you're going there for the first time, I'd recommend you try Mandarin Chicken. I like their Lemon Chicken too. Ma Por Tofu is spicy enough.

A downside is, it's so small that you're likely to have to wait on weekends unless you have a reservation.
author: Haruki E.

description:
If I was writing this review 2.5 years ago it would have been 5 stars. We discovered this little gem a couple of years ago and it's popularity was still relatively in check. Since then the secret of this little Chinese restaurant in West Portal
is out and unfortunately I fear the quality of the food has gone down. The reason we went here religiously every week was for the freshness and intricacy of tastes. Now the food is still better than most standard Chinese restaurants but for the price I expect more. The one good thing, they truly don't use MSG. The house lamb dish is still delicious as is their chive and prawn dumplings. The chicken fried rice used to be quite good but they stopped seasoning the chicken and now it is quite bland. Even my foodie SF child won't eat it.  We still visit this restaurant but not with the same frequency and mostly as an excuse to make a run to Ambassador Toys at the end of
dinner.
author: Halima T.

description:
Eh.

It was good but kinda pricey.  Kinda what you expect in the West Portal.  However, the service was great and the atmosphere is very nice.  Enjoyed the Hunan Spicy Chicken but the beef chow mein was just weird tasting.
author: Mark O.

description: A solid "meh."  Service was a little lacking - I asked about the tea selection and was met  with a blank stare.  I found the dishes to be bland.  That said, service was quick and friendly and the decor was charming.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
Laundry done, time for an adventure.  Asparagus is just about in season.  Fog isn't quite yet.  A quick Le Mans drive up over Portola, I whisked myself, my laundry, and my buddy out of the urine-smelling mission and into the land of West Portal.  

Crispy, savory, spicy "dry fried" asparagus.  Delicious.  
Wok-flashed szcheuan pork.  OK.
Cannon-ball sized pork/shrimp pot stickers.  Not as good as my cousins matzoh balls from Monday night but just as satisfying.  mmm.

Loong drive is worth it
author: Jon B.

description: A Chinese restaurant that doesn't serve tea. Very odd to me. I got the sweet and sour lunch special. Terrible. No flavor. The orange they provided was dirty! Just unacceptable. I have also been here for dinner and the prices are just way too high. $10 entrees doesn't justify the quality and quantity. Wonton soup is at least double the price of other restaurants.  I wasn't a fan of the atmosphere either. I felt as though I was in a cafeteria.
author: Jessica M.

description: Whoever thinks that Chinese food has to be greasy and without inspiration has not been to Xiao Loong. They do delicious Chinese food that offers the complete opposite of the cheap Chinese restaurants that populate the City. You will pay a bit more, but it's totally worth it. Their soups are warm and comforting, their noodles are tasty and their lemon chicken is fabulous. Try one of their many appetizers and you are sure not to be disappointed. They also deliver and when the food shows up it's hot and just like you're having it at the restaurant. After a dinner at Xiao Loong you'll have a whole different outlook on Chinese.
author: Rebecca D.

description: The flavors aren't bad, but this isn't a "real" Chinese restaurant. The decor is non-descript, the restaurant is small but comfortable. It really caters to those who want a Chinese meal but isn't completely comfortable with the mom and pop style of Chinese cuisine. Xiao Loong serves up all the traditional types of dishes without the authentic flair. Dishes have been modified to give it more of a Western flair. Nice place to go with friends who aren't familiar with Chinese food, but for hard core Chinese food lovers, this is not the place for you.
author: Anita L.

description:
I'm a fan!

The food was delicious, and appropriately priced. The service was amazing... they were on top of everything. The cups never ran dry, and that's huge for me. 

Pros: Attentive friendly service, fair prices for portion sizes, convenient location, clean bright atmosphere.

Cons: My coke was served in a tiny little glass bottle, which was cute, but I lost 2 oz. from can size, Kung Pao chicken had no kick (If it says hot I want it to burn me).

Definitely a place I'll recommend to others, and go again myself! :)
author: Jonathan I.

description: Jeffrey & the entire staff at Xiao Loong do an outstanding job serving up piping-hot, fresh & delicious, Chinese food! The Chicken Salad (with the peanut dressing) is CRAZY GOOD & the lamb dishes are MUST TRIES! Oh, & don't forget the prawn dishes either! Writing this review is making me hungry for XIAO LOONG!
author: Jody A.

description: Tis all about about the mu shu pork and the giant pork dumplings. They are the size of a small lemon. Order them, and you shall be happy. That is all. Beep.
author: Christopher K.

description: I really like this place. It's a great spot to stop in with the kids. Great food. Nice place. Nice staff.  I eat there frequently.
author: Michael S.

description:
I've never been here for dinner but the lunch is something very special. 

It's really cheap (like 6-8 dollars) for what should be a filling lunch to anyone with a healthy (ie not a compulsive or even consistent over-eater) appetite. 

I got some spicy prawns that were really good, and my friend got the calamari. Both were delicious. 

The restaurant itself is pleasant and clean and zen as other's have mentioned. If you work near West Portal it's hard to beat the lunch special.
author: Jake R.

description: Visiting from So. CA and our son took us to Xiao Loong.  We all enjoyed it very much.  I had the Vegetarian Pot Stickers and Vegetable Mu Shu which I asked them to add tofu to, and they gladly did.  Even asked if I wanted the tofu fried or steamed.  My husband and son shared a small Sizzling Rice Soup (which was not so small), the regular Pot Stickers which have Pork, Xiao Loong Beef, Dry Sautéed Asparagus and Brown Rice.  Serving sizes were nice and we took home leftovers of everything except the soup.  My husband is always worried about getting beef dishes in Chinese restaurants because many times it is tough.  He said this was very good..
author: Caryn C.

description:
from my friend angela's review: I WAS "THAT FRIEND"  :)
-1 -1 -1 -1 -1 (how can mess up the dish that you're named after???)
"It was all right. My friend and I came here on the false pretense that their xiao long baos were going to be bomb (they were featured on 7x7). Unfortunately, they turned out to be mediocre at best. They were massive looking xiao long baos that had no soup in them. Sometimes, bigger is not better. "

+1 decor is much nicer and cleaner than other dumpling houses
+1 jiaozi were tasty, but not enough to drive back there

live and learn. kingdom of dumpling is still #1 for me!
author: Dora F.

description: I have not been disappointed here yet. Excellent to go food. Nice place to dine in as well. The shrimp w/lobster sauce is exceptional, fresh sauteed spinach cooked to perfection.(hard to do when ordering to go) Every item is always consistent and fresh. A nice addition to the West Portal area.
author: Dee D.

description: One of my neighborhood favorites. I love their Spicy Chili Prawns and Dry Sauteed Green Beans. The restaurant is quite small though so be aware that it can get pretty loud at times, particularly when you have a boisterous birthday group next to you.
author: Lauren K.

description:
This is one of SF's great hidden gems.  The owner (Jeff) is always a gracious host and has an incredible memory for faces and names.  It is a contemporary Chinese menu but comprised of all the classics.

I would highly recommend their sizzling rice soup.  It is light and fresh and won't weigh you down.  

I've tried just about every dish.  Some are heavier than others but they are all delicious.  Regardless of the entree you choose, the spicy green beans are a must have.
author: P K.

description:
This is where I go for a change of pace from the Sunset and Richmond chinese restaurant dives. Yes, each plate is a couple bucks more but Xiao Loong makes some tasty americanized Chinese food. I always leave this place happy and content.  Another great thing is that you could get a glass of wine when dining in.

The potstickers and Xiao Loong baos with the homemade skin are a must to start (better in house vs. take-out).....the seaweed and garden soups are delicious if you're into brothy and light soups......and of course the tasty dishes like xiao loong beef, dry fried chicken/prawns, brocolli/tofu with the nice sesame seeds touch are all.....YUMMY!
author: BlissChic W.

description: This place is amazing! Anyone who's given it a mediocre view is clearly just unhappy with life. Usually, Chinese is my least favorite of Asian fare, because of the grease factor. But this place always delights! Food A+. Service A+
author: Maria D.

description: This place is overpriced. The waiter came and took our soy sauce half way through our meal and gave it to another table, which I thought was a bit tacky. Otherwise, the service was good and the food was pretty tasty.
author: Patrick S.

description: Dry sautéed asparagus were fantastic. Also liked the steamed vegetarian pot stickers. The Xiao Loong's Steamed Fish was less successful as it was very bland, but several splashes of chili oil and soy sauce changed that. A very clean and serene atmosphere.
author: Bleep S.

description:
What mixed reviews.

The negatives are listed as Over Priced and Unauthentic.

Its in the West Portal - an Upscale neighborhood, so the price reflects the rent of the building, not the greed of the owners.

The food is very good, and who wants 'authentic' at every meal. Wouldn't all the ethnic  restaurants taste the same if that was the only way to prepare a meal?
author: dan s.

description: Great place, great service and awesome food.  I really enjoy the Vegetarian Pot Stickers, it is worth waiting 15 minutes for them to be cooked.
author: Edwin C.

description:
We eat here regularly and think it's one of the best Chinese restaurants in the City.  Dishes are $10 or so - considerably more than the avg chinese greasy-spoon - but the food quality is very good.   Table space is small so be warned that it can get very crowded.  Service is good/competent.

We've noticed more variabiity in the sauces in the last few months, maybe kithcen turnover.  Even so, the quality remains high even if the dish is prepared differently than any previous visit.  Take-out is fast/reliable.
author: G T S.

description: The place was ok... customer service is better then average, food tasted ok, but not incredible. The shrimp they served us smelled really bad... they just gave us another place that was much better. Mongolian beef was good, but different than it usually is. Its a bit more pricy than most other Chinese restaurants, but still tolerable.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Great food!  Great staff!  Great value.

Their lunch specials are off the hook.
author: Craig L.

description: While we are enormous fans of the West Portal neighborhood, this is the ONE restaurant that it makes sense for you to travel from anywhere in the Bay Area to visit. (And it is directly on the muni line (K,L,M or T to West Portal, or K & M to just about the front door). The design of the space is beautiful and the food is fantastic. An extraordinary find in any part of San Francisco.
author: Lawrence L.

description: We feel so lucky that this excellent restaurant is in our neighborhood--we go to it often! Fresh, well-flavored, never greasy, always high quality--Xiao Loong has spoiled us for most other Chinese restaurants. But it's not just the good food, it's the lovely service. All of the staff are warm, personable and professional. I always appreciated the service but this morning the service went above and beyond: last night my daughter had a friend visiting from out of town, and we took her Xiao Loong of course, because she wanted Chinese food.  The girl left her purse in the restaurant, which included her boarding pass for her flight the next afternoon (when the restaurant would be closed). I emailed the owner and he called me back immediately--on an early Sunday morning. They had the purse, they had tried to find us after we left the night before, AND he met me at the restaurant, on his morning off, to open up and give us the purse. Now, that is service--and a shout to West Portal too, for having such a lovely small town feel in the middle of our big city. Great good and great service--both the expected kind (in the restaurant) and the unexpected (on a Sunday morning, when it was closed!).
author: Sharon E.

description: We just ate there again tonight and, as usual, it was absolutely wonderful. I'm always tempted to order the same fantastic dishes (mushu chicken, hot/sour soup, shrimp in lobster sauce to name a few) but then I go and try something new and it becomes a new favorite! The staff is super nice and the restaurant itself is very charming.
author: Andrew B.

description: Yummy place with a nice ambiance. We prefer it for Chinese food in the area.
author: Kate R.

description:
its not your typical chinese resturant.   its like grabbing for the fiji water bottler over the arrowhead.  its just water... do you really need the fancy bottle? sometimes, i like fancy things =) 

great food, great service great atmo, slightly overpriced for chinese food BUT THE QUALITY OF INGREDIANTS HOLDS THE 4STARS.  Ive had plenty of chinese food, and they all taste good going down, but how do you feel after?  disguted?  MSGed out?  dehydration?  Here... umm none of the above.  gets a thumbs up from me.  

i also might be biased because i'm in love with the tattoo girl that work sthere... strait GANGSTA!
author: Doug ..

description: This is our go-to spot for the nights we just don't feel like cooking. We've been there dozens of times, and we've ALWAYS left perfectly satisfied. It might not be "authentic," but that's not what they're trying to be. The quality is excellent and consistent, and service is very friendly and non-intimidating to those who aren't familiar with Chinese food, as Anita M. says. Our favorites are the House Chicken, Lemon Pepper Prawns, Dry Fried Calamari, and Hot Braised Fish, and Dry Sauteed Green Beans. CineArts movie theatre is a block away--perfect for a dinner-and-a-movie date night!
author: Jen C.

description: This place is great.  Most chinese food tastes like takeout and this is the first chinese food place that actually tastes like a home made meal.  The pot stickers are amazing and so is the prawns and snow peas.
author: T D.

description: We love this restaurant because the food is fresh and delicious, the owner is often there  - ensuring all runs smoothly, and it's consistent.  Dining in, it can get a little loud (I like that it's kid-friendly but could be helpful to place some sound panels on the wall).  We pick-up to-go food often and the food stays hot (10 min drive) and is never greasy.  We always order the braised fish and also really like the mu shu. Enjoy!
author: lily k.

description: A and I came here for dinner yesterday.  Apparently he frequents this place a lot.  He was craving some Xiao Loong Bao, which is what he ordered as an appetizer.  They weren't bad.  I've had better, but they were pretty good.  We also had brown rice, Xiao Loong Beef, and Bok Choy with Shiitake Mushrooms.  The food was actually good.  You could tell this is more of an Americanized Chinese restaurant.  It's not to say that the food isn't authentic, but it's definitely Americanized.  The space is small, but really cute.  The service was great.  Everyone was super attentive and we got everything really fast.  It was probably about $30 for everything for the two of us.  If I were in the area and wanted some Chinese food, yes, I'd go back.
author: Kris L.

description: We had dinner here tonight.  Tonight was the first time it was open when we've passed it after a Stern Grove concert so I was excited to try it, since I am a big fan of xiao long bao, and with the restaurant named after the dish, what else am I supposed to expect but great succulent baos, right?  It turned out that they were actually the most disappointing dish we ordered.  We were already forewarned when the server brought our order to us without the traditional dipping sauce of shredded young ginger in red vinegar.  They did make it for us when we asked for it.  But when we tried the dumplings, we knew immediately that they were quite off.  They were way to big, making them hard to eat in 1 bite, and the soup inside ended up leaking out instead of just bursting in your mouth.  The dough was also quite thick, more suitable for potstickers, which was a much better dish of the 2 that we ordered.  We also ordered the dry sauteed green beans, so fresh and crunchy, just the way I expected it to be.  The service is friendly, the decor is modern Chinese.  So, yes, I will be happy to go back, just not for the xiao long bows, but you knew that already...
author: Yvette F.

description:
I have been to Xiao Loong Restaurant many times and it is always a nice experience. The decor is very modern, the staff very inviting. Their prices are very affordable and the food is always delicious. They have the best potstickers ever, I also love the hot and sour soup (portions are very generous) and the taste is incredible and this is just the appetizers that I am talking about. Now, for the main courses: I highly recommend a few items; such as the Mongolian Beef Tender sliced beef sautéed with green onions, julienned yellow onions, and roasted red. I also love the spicy Sichuan egg plant. Fresh Japanese eggplant, braised with our spicy Sichuan garlic sauce and last but not least the Hunan steamed fish ... simply to die for it is  fresh daily- fish steamed with roasted red hot peppers, fermented black beans, minced fresh ginger, and chopped garlic in their own house Chinese wine sauce. hot peppers in our house sauce served on a bed of crispy rice noodles.  

This is a great place to take a date and/or go with  family. I highly recommend this place.
author: Ernesto C.

description: What a treat! Very impressed all round. The ambiance was professional and elegant (not the typical Chinese restaurant decor); the service was efficient and expeditious, the prices were MORE THAN reasonable, but the food was the real star!!! Everything was flavorful, with clear flavor palettes and unmuddled taste profiles; The WON-TON soup was flavorful and delicious, a pleasant change from the limp dumplings in dishwater that so many Chinese restaurants pass off on unsuspecting eaters! The Mongolian Beef was very flavorful and well presented, with crisp yet not overpowering flavors; The shrimp with 5 Chinese spices was amazing: just the right combination of sweet/hot.. amazing flavor profile! And the Lemon chicken... I have to admit I wasn't the one in our group that ordered it because I am so used to lemon chicken being over-coated and drenched in lemon "goop" that tastes like lemon AJAX dish soap.. but THIS lemon chicken was moist, pleasantly lightly coated with a gentle batter, and the lemon sauce was a sauce and not a glop, with a crisp and cleansing citrus flavor that complimented the sweet hot of the shrimp and the deep flavor of the beef! Overall... a definite gem to add to your repertoire! The only reason I didn't give it five stars was that i don't give out 5 stars unless its a once-in a -lifetime experience.. Xiao Loong is awesome, but not quite THAT awesome LOL!!
author: Mark H.

description: Hey! A chinese restaurant that looks pretty nice.  It's in the fancy West Portal area, so it has to look the part.  The spring rolls are good.  And the rest of the food is pretty decent.  The menu is pricier than your run of the mill chinese restaurant.  So, you're paying for a better atmosphere with some tlc.
author: Sam T.

description: We were at the Manor Coffee Shop and saw an article that talked about restaurants in the area which noted Xiao Loong. We are Din Tai Fung Foodies (Down in SoCal, Arcadia - best Dumpling House ever) so we are always interested in something out here. We only tried two items since we had just finished lunch but we somehow always have room to try out new stuff. The family ordered the Fried Won Ton which had a filling and the Xiao Long Bao, To- Go, of which we loved both items. The wrapper was a bit thicker on the Xiao Long Bao than what we prefer but the filling was very flavorful and good sized. Although, we live about 50 minutes away in the East Bay we plan to come back and try some of the other dishes. The menu sounded very good and hitting 2 out of 2 on the take-out, we suspect we will find other dishes that we will like. It is hard to find good Xiao Long Bao but we are always game to see something, stop, order it to go and eat it in the car...in search of great food. We liked Xiao Loong.
author: Henry D.

description: If you're expecting authentic chinese food, maybe you shouldn't be in west portal. I don't understand the 1-star reviews of this place, it really is not THAT bad. The atmosphere is really nice and the servers were friendly and awkwardly cute. My meal was good, nicely portioned, and very fresh tasting. Having said that, the little chile pepper icon in the menu warning that a particular item is "hot" is a joke. I've had ice cream that was spicier.
author: Wayne F.

description: I've only gotten food from here a few times, and i'm still trying to find my favorite main dishes; However, i already know what's going to keep bringing me back - the prawn and chinese chive dumplings. They are unbelievably good.
author: Grem W.

description: Very yummy and fresh Chinese food. They deliver in the area. You can order take out or eat in the cute restaurant on West Portal Avenue. My 5.5 year old son especially likes the fried won tons (not the cream cheese kind) and my daugher (3 years old) loves the chow mein. It doesn't have the bean sprout fillers that other restaurants include. We either take out or eat in 2x a month.
author: Beth A.

description: We have eaten in and gotten take out about a half-dozen times in the last few months, and have been consistently pleased. We used to live in Noe Valley, and Eric's and Alice's were staples for us. Since moving to Westlake, we hadnt found anything we liked as well until we stumbled onto Xiao Loong. West Portal isnt West Lake, but it is well worth the short ride for a delicious meal. Love love love the calamari.
author: Tom C.

description: This restaurant is clean, tasty, and gives reasonable portions that won't make you have to throw away half your food. I recommend the Gao Lan lamb, the Chinese chicken salad and the Xiao Loong beef.
author: Jessica O.

description: It was my first time visit on a Friday night. Several tables were available and we were seated right away. We didn't know what to order and asked for a few more minutes because the waitress almost immediately returned after she gave us the menus. Big mistake because it took quite awhile to get the waitress' attention after wards. We ended up ordering the dry string beans, happy family seafood medley with vegetables, and the lemon chicken. The string beans was the highlight. The seafood medley was bland and the calamari did not taste fresh. The lemon chicken was a deep fried chicken breast on top of a gooey gelatinous mound of shredded cabbage. The portions were good but I would not order 2 out of the 3 dishes I had again. Service was okay.
author: Edmund W.

description: If I'd written this review 8 or 9 months ago it would be 4 or maybe even 5 stars.  The last few meals have been disappointing.  Rice was still tasty, but all the other dishes were off.  Stuff that was supposed to be spicy wasn't, the chicken that used to be nice pieces, is now scrawny unrecognizable bits.  As of now, I'm looking for a new easy to get to chinese place.  Xiao Loong does have a nice atmosphere though and I like the service.
author: Sam T.

description: Mmmmmm !! I love this place! Their food is great and the place is clean! Service is always good too.
author: Nicole L.

description: the most f**k up chinese restaurant.  It is run by teenagers that don't have knowledge whatsoever with customer service, especially the guy with the glasses, he's rude, never admit his mistake, and looks and act childish.  I hate their food, service, and the atmosphere.
author: Albert W.

description:
My favorite chinese restaurant!!

I moved to the east coast a few years back and I've missed Xiao Loong ever since!  I've gotten take out since I've been gone and it's still the best.  Can't go wrong with anything on the menu!  

I dream of the Xiao Loong Bao, dry fried chicken, tofu and broccoli, gai lan, lychee iced tea...i could go on forever!  

The service is GREAT and Jeff is fantastic.  Everyone is very attentive and so helpful.
author: Teresa W.

description: I ordered out from this place today and found it to be not good. The pot stickers were better than the chicken chow fun . . . but I'd be hard pressed to return there for a full meal.
author: Todd F.

description: This is our favorite "take-out" chinese restaurant in our neighborhood.  Okay so as the other posters have commented its not that -authentic and not worth the trip across town if you live out of the area but the dishes are tasty, good quality, not greasy and the help is friendly.  We like lemon pepper prawns, soft tofu & brocoli, curry chicken, lemon chicken and mu shu pork.
author: Michelle M.

description: this is a great restaurant with delicious!!!! food, but when they closed the doors in front of me and 3 more of my friends recently 7!!!!! minutes BEFORE actual closing time... i was doubting if i ever come back.........
author: ina a.

description: This restaurant was a huge disappointment. My friend and I ordered the prawn mushu which was so-so, and then I ordered this pepper prawn dish while my friend ordered the Mongolian beef. Apparently the latter was decent, but my pepper prawn dish was pretty bad. To top it all, the waitresses seemed distant and the whole experience was unsatisfactory. Go to Eric's!
author: Matin N.

description: We've been eating at Xiao Loong regularly for about 4 years now.  But I haven't reviewed it, because I'd rather keep it a secret.  Great food, and great service here!  Prices are reasonable.  And, for vegetarians, here's the best secret:  you can order just about anything on the menu with tofu substituted.  Our faves are: Cheng Bi Chicken, with fried tofu substituted, Hunan steamed fish (with tofu instead of fish).  Other favorites:  the potstickers (veggie variety available), pork bows (sorry, not veggie),  sauteed string beans with minced preserved turnip.  If you like mild fish, try the Shandong Braised Fish.  Everything here is flavorful and not overdone.
author: Penelope M.

description:
i wish i can give this place "0" star !!!

seriously, dont go to this mad rest. 

- taste: 0
- cleanliness: 0
- service: 0 ( can i put minus on zero ? )

every minute of my experience is just like domino effect. getting worse and worse. i cant believe that someone actually recommend me to this place ! 

Run and save your money and your ass, you'll thank me later.
author: sherly A.

description: Xiao Loong definitely beats out any other Chinese restaurant out there. The food is prepared freshly and serves all sauces on the side, rather than drenching any items with sauce. Xiao Loong also offers free delivery, and never takes more than one hour. Prices may be a little more than the typical Chinese restaurant, but the spectacular food is worth every cent! Parking in West Portal may be a little hard, especially at night, but the neighborhood offers multiple parking lots and residential parking.
author: Kevin H.

description: Good atmosphere, food, and service. My husband and I have eaten here several times and were happy with every dish we've had from the xiao loong biao to the green beans to the clay pot dishes. We pay a bit more than the average Chinese restaurant but it's worth it since the ingredients are always fresh and the service is always perfect! Plus, we never have to wait for a table. Or for extra water or tea since the service staff is always attentive to the customers! Would go back to eat any time!
author: Felicia S.

description: It's no Dragonwell, but I really do like Xiao Loong. We moved to the area about a year ago and I would say that we order from here about once a week. It's totally consistent and they have some pretty delicious dishes (Sichuan Dry Fried Prawns) and their Mushu is pretty good, too.
author: Michelle B.

description: The food here is very good and very consistent. I have been here twice and just about every dish that we ordered was good and well received by our party. Oh, and we were all Asian, so I don't think that only non-Asian customers think the food is good here. Our parents are all great cooks so we know what good Asian food is supposed to taste like! The space is on the small side but very clean, modern, and zen. Oh and the fortune cookies are the best!!
author: Lori E.

description:
I've eaten at this restaurant many times.... I don't any longer.  The so-called "House Chicken" is rarely prepared with the same level of consistency in flavor, sauce, and I counted 6 - yes, 6 - black beans the last time I ordered it. Disappointing to say the least.  Very, very laden with sodium (but then, isn't most Chinese food soaked in salt-laden sauce?) - an hour and a half later I'm chugging glass-after-glass of water.  On one account I returned the house chicken because it was badly overcooked and very tough.  Some of the pieces are far too large to put in your mouth - and no knives are provided to easily cut it (not with chopsticks, of course).  Few dishes are offered without soy sauce (an issue for wheat allergic or gluten intolerant).

Jeff, the owner, is pleasant and courteous although the wait staff is socially sterile and devoid of any pleasantries - not even a reciprocated smile. Crowded tables make for little privacy and intimacy.  I see similar behavior at most Chinese restaurants.

Prices? You'll get a LOT more for your money at Eric's on Church St. with more choices (but substantially more rude waiters). Yes, Xiao Loong is pricey in contrast with MANY other nearby Chinese restaurants. Clean, yes, but NOT standout in ambience - whatsoever.  I REFUSE to buy a pot of Jeff's tea - outrageously overpriced.  Eric's: no charge for a pot.

Nonetheless, I'm finding myself gravitating elsewhere - largely back to Noe Valley - Church and Sanchez Chinese restaurants (despite even much worse parking!)
author: William S.

description: This isn't REAL Asian food but it is better than most!  The atmosphere is very relaxing.  The service is fantastic!  The wine and tea lists are extensive.  We especially like the green beans, the wontons, the dry fried chicken, the steamed fish, the....Oh, I guess we like the whole menu.  We've never had a bad meal at Xiao Loong.  It's hard to find because there's a big tree in front that blocks the whole store front.  Find it and you won't be disappointed.
author: Martin S.

description:
I think its one of the better chinese restaurants in the city (for my taste).
Try the House Chicken, beans and spicy shrimp.
The place isn't too expensive either.
author: sachin n.

description:
This is an excellent neighborhood Chinese restaurant.  They have a few outstanding dishes, such as the lemon pepper prawns and (of all things) vegetable chow mein.  The latter has large pieces of vegetables, not little diced pieces.  We have had mostly the vegetable entrees, so I can't comment on the rest of the menu.

Many of the lunch specials are disappointing, with gloppy brown sauce on everything.
author: William W.

description: As long as you expect to get Chinese food for the American palate, this place is decent.  I came here for lunch which is a good deal for this "trendy" Chinese restaurant.  It came with soup and an appetizer.  I half thought they forgot to give us the appetizer but then looked at the other tables and realized others didn't get anything we didn't - though I'm not sure if the little bowl of pickled vegetables should qualify as an appetizer. For the price, I can't complain.  I ordered the clay pot shrimp and tofu and unfortunately, it was nothing like I expected.  It didn't come out in a claypot and had none of the aromatic goodness a clay pot dish usually has. It was pretty bland but at least, I felt like I was eating healthy.  A picture of his dish is posted. My friend had the spicy calamari which wasn't so spicy and had that sticky sweet sauce.  Not authentic but still tasty and satisfying in the same way that Panda Express orange chicken is.  As I walked out, I noticed a couple of other customers with noodle dishes that looked hearty and tasty.  Probably not somewhere I'd go for dinner, but I'd come back again at lunch for another rice plate or noodle dish.
author: Amina B.

description: I don't know what the other reviewers are talkinga bout, because this place is fantastic.  I've been going there since they opened - they've been around for several years and you KNOW a chinese place doesn't stay open for long in SF if it's not good.  Maybe you have to know which dishes to order: Hong Kong style cripsy noodles, eggplant in garlic sauce, dry fried squid, moo shu pork - excellent, excellent
author: M T.

description: So the first time I wen here, the food was pretty good --been back a couple more times and have really been disappointed.  Maybe they got a new chef or something but the foods not that great.
author: Jane R.

description: I've eaten at Xiao Loong a few times now and I'm impressed.  The food has always been very good.  The service is excellent (friendly, attentive without being oppressive, etc).  A word of caution ... the dumplings on the appetizer list are HUGE!  They're wonderful, but the evening we ordered the dumplings AND entrees we were stuffed and we still took things home in boxes!  Enjoy!
author: Dwight S.

description: Food is great!  Atmosphere is clean and modern.  Management is professional and very personable.  A truly yummy experience without the grossness of chinatown.
author: J B.

description: It was a brisk night, a light fog was kept away by the steady pace of the offshore coastal flow.  I was hungry.  To my left a homeless person let out a shriek that verified I was in the Mission.  It was time to leave.  A short walk later found me in Jon B.'s subaru looking for shelter from the chaos that my 'hood represents.  Jon knew what I was feeling, he didn't have to ask.  He felt it too.  We drove to the west portal because with a name like that, how could we not.  West we went, and quick, the Giants would soon finish losing against my beloved Padres, and the throngs of orange and black would hit the street angry and bitter.   A fearsome sight the depressed fair-weather fan... gnarled and broken like so many syringes on the MUNI tracks.  We hurried.  Parking was a pleasure, I commented to Jon as much, he laughed as though I had told him I just slept with his sister... awkward but understanding, with a hint of feined purpose.  We were seated quickly at Xiao Loong, the host was pleasant and brought water.  Pot stickers (the size of which I had never laid eyes on) arrived, followed by fresh asparagus and a forgettable pork dish, the collective of which soon justified our trek to the outer reaches of space-time, Gene Ray was right when he said that  creation occurs via opposites, some nights just go that way. No words were exchanged after the meal, nothing remained to be said, this was good, and although a return was inevitable, the mission awaited.  It was calling.  As was Lost.  Darkness had set, the Giants did lose... I kept the faith.
author: Darren R.
